awd_titl_txt: CAREER: SusChEM: Development of Manganese Hydrosilylation Catalysts for Silicone Curing
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Ryan Trovitch of Arizona State University is studying ways to make catalysts from abundant metals, such as manganese, that can be used to prepare silicone polymers.  Polymers are long chain molecules that derive many of their properties from the entanglements and interactions between the chains.  Polymers have become ubiquitous materials in our daily lives, impacting most industries, including agriculture and food, health and safety, as well as transportation.  For more than half a century, silicone polymers have been used in a variety of consumer products including contact lenses, flexible tubing, and medical implants. Most catalysts that are widely employed in silicone preparation and curing are based on precious metals such as platinum or iridium, relatively toxic elements that are costly to obtain due to their low abundance in the Earth's crust.  The development of manganese-based catalysts for silicone preparation would have the potential to supplant precious metal catalyst use, which would represent a significant advance in sustainable chemistry.  Professor Trovitch is also working to enhance student and public familiarity with green chemistry.  He is developing a sustainability workshop for local high school students, and videos based upon this program will be made available to achieve broad dissemination.  As an Advisory Board Member of the Green Chemistry Commitment, he is participating in ongoing initiatives to introduce undergraduate and graduate students to advanced topics in sustainable chemistry through updated coursework and laboratory experiences.  Professor Trovitch is also organizing Science Cafe discussions in collaboration with the Phoenix Public Library.  


In this project, Prof. Ryan J. Trovitch of Arizona State University is developing sustainable manganese hydrosilylation catalysts that will exhibit comparable activity and selectivity to widely used precious metal catalysts.  Relative to second and third row transition metals, manganese remains underutilized in catalytic applications due to its propensity to participate in one-electron reaction pathways.  Recent results have shown that polydentate, redox non-innocent chelate ligands enable manganese-catalyzed carbonyl hydrosilylation by reversibly transferring electrons and partially dissociating throughout catalysis. Building on this discovery, Professor Trovitch is studying several aspects of manganese-catalyzed hydrosilylation reactions including manganese olefin hydrosilylation catalysts that can serve as replacements for ones based upon platinum, novel carbonyl hydrosilylation pathways to crosslink polyones with polyhydrosilanes or polyhydrosiloxanes, and dehydrogenative silylation pathways to the synthesis of siloxane networks.  Via electronic structure determinations and mechanistic studies, highly active manganese catalysts for olefin hydrosilylation, carbonyl hydrosilylation, and dehydrogenative silylation are being developed by judiciously modifying their ligand frameworks.  Successful completion of this project will transform current knowledge of manganese catalysis while revealing potential advantages of high-denticity redox non-innocent chelate utilization.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

The global silicone industry generates sales of greater than $15 billion annually while offering solutions for the medical, automotive, and household product industries. Approximately 40% of all silicone is cured through the hydrosilylation of alkene-substituted siloxanes with hydride-functionalized siloxanes, a transformation that allows for the production of medical grade tubing, gaskets, and kitchenware. Platinum catalysts are very effective for this purpose; however, platinum is not found in great abundance on Earth, and its rarity can result in high costs to the companies that rely on it.

This project sought to evaluate whether manganese, which is widely available and inexpensive, could be used in place of platinum to catalyze silicone curing. To directly replace platinum, a manganese hydride catalyst was prepared, characterized, and found to be effective for the hydrosilylation of alkenes. This catalyst was then used to hydrosilylate alkene-functionalized monomers with hydride-functionalized siloxanes to prepare silicone materials that are commonly used for smartphone screen coatings, implants, and contact lenses. 

This project also sought to develop manganese and related Earth-abundant metal catalysts for the hydrosilylation of carbonyl-containing compounds. As commonly practiced for alkene hydrosilylation, the hydrosilylation of a compound containing two or more carbonyl groups has been found to result in silicone polymers. During this project, two base metal catalysts were discovered that held (and currently hold) the record for ambient temperature carbonyl hydrosilylation activity. Initially, it was determined that a bis(imino)pyridine manganese dimer was capable of hydrosilylating aldehydes with turnover frequencies of up to 4,950 min-1 (relative to the amount of manganese present). A structurally related aryl diimine cobalt catalyst was subsequently found to mediate carbonyl hydrosilylation with turnover frequencies of up to 330 s-1. In a related study, a nickel catalyst that could hydrosilylate esters with turnover frequencies of up to 990 h-1 was discovered, representing the highest activity ever observed for ester cleavage.

Overall, this project has impacted the field of chemistry in a few key ways. Interest in developing Earth-abundant metal catalysts has continued to grow, and contributions from this project changed the way that chemists think about base metal catalyst development. For example, most manganese catalysts are monovalent, diamagnetic, and octahedral; however, this project has demonstrated that there is plenty of opportunity to develop manganese catalysts that feature other oxidation states and geometries. This project also demonstrated that highly conjugated ligands that feature phosphine groups can improve the efficiency of base metal hydrosilylation catalysis, and in several cases allow for unprecedented activity.

This project resulted in the publication of 13 manuscripts, including articles in Accounts of Chemical Research, Journal of the American Chemical Society, and Chemical Science. These papers have been cited more than 400 times and two of the catalysts used for this work are now commercially available. The science discovered during this project also contributed to 3 invention disclosures, 2 granted patents, and a book chapter on manganese based hydrosilylation catalysis. This research was featured in more than 20 invited lectures and more than 10 student-presented conference talks and posters. 

Broader Impacts

This initiative supported the training of undergraduate and graduate students in the synthetic skills required to prepare and evaluate the effectiveness of new base metal catalysts. The students who participated on this project have gone on to join highly competitive graduate programs and work for multinational corporations in the chemical, semiconductor, and biopharmaceutical industries. This project also formed the foundation of training programs that encourage the participation of early stage researchers and support their transition to graduate school.

The researchers who contributed to this project developed videos of inorganic laboratory experiments while constructing a sustainability-focused manual. Related education and outreach efforts have impacted the training of students at other institutions. By improving the sustainability of widely-practiced undergraduate laboratory experiments and disseminating this material to the broader scientific community through non-profit and corporate partners, has project meaningfully enhanced student access to green chemistry course content. Through concurrent service on the Green Chemistry Commitment advisory board, a 433% increase in the number of signing institutions was realized, an achievement that will result in expanded green chemistry education at the college level, both nationally and internationally.
